chapter.title: Understanding the differences
chapter.content:
Understanding the differences

There is a difference between learning preferences, learning difficulties, and learning disabilities. This topic examines each term closely to understand their meaning.

chapter.title: Learning preferences
chapter.content:
Learning preferences

Learning preferences are conditions of learning that one finds helpful. Some of us are great in the morning; others of us are better at night. Some like charts or graphs; others prefer a story. Some like to discuss; others prefer to listen.

Having a learning preference does not mean that a person who likes to discuss cannot learn from a lecture, or that a night owl cannot learn in the morning. Learning preferences are ways of learning that are helpful but not necessary.

Learning preferences are represented by the largest circle because they apply to all of us.

chapter.title: Learning difficulties
chapter.content:
Learning difficulties

Learning difficulties arise when a specific task or circumstance in the learning environment inhibits an individual’s ability to learn. Examples include having to listen to someone speak in a monotone, trying to pay attention in a very cold or hot room, or attending a lecture with no opportunity for questions and answers. These are conditions that make learning difficult for many of us.

Learning difficulties can extend to specific learning tasks. For example, it is not uncommon for an individual to be good at math but find it difficult to stay motivated to finish reading a novel. Another person may be gifted at understanding history concepts but be challenged in memorizing dates.

chapter.title: Learning disabilities
chapter.content:
Learning disabilities

Learning disabilities are represented by a smaller circle because they apply to only some of us in any given situation.

Learning disabilities is a legal term for a neurological condition within the individual that makes one or more of the processes associated with learning extremely difficult.

Individuals with LD are protected by laws and have legal rights. Thus “Learning disabilities” are represented by the smallest circle in our diagram, because this designation is applicable to only a specific group of learners.

chapter.title: Activity: Build a working definition of LD
chapter.content:
Activity: Build a working definition of LD

Let’s explore your current understanding of LD. This activity asks you to use your answers to three questions to build a working definition of LD based on your knowledge and experience. Use a blank piece of paper to write your responses.

  1. First, consider your own perspective on learning disabilities. How would you define LD. For example, how would you explain LD to a student?
  2. Next, consider LD from a programmatic perspective. How does your organization define LD?
  3. Then, consider how LD affects an individual. What are some examples of behaviors that would indicate that an individual may haved a learning disability?
  4. Now, considering each of your answers to the first three questions, generate a working definition of LD based on your knowledge and experience.

We will ask you to refer back to your definition at the end of this lesson. As we move on to examine others’ perspectives, you will see that there are many different opinions about the definition of LD.
